data.title: Adding option to skip main process tests. Cleaning up resources in tests
data.body:
The main process tests take some time to complete, to improve the inner loop when working on features I have added the commandline option to skip these tests.

I have also cleaned up a duplicate import and added some resource cleanup to a few existing tests.

**Note**: These changes are extracted from my now abandoned PR #14456

data.title: Cannot install Atom on CentOS 6
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* CentOS 6.9
* Kernel `2.6.32-696.6.3.el6.x86_64`

### Description

There is an inability to install atom text editor as it has a dependency on `libsecret-1` which is not made available to CentOS6.

### Versions

This occurs in all version of atom which a dependency on `libsecret-1`.  From version below, including, 1.17.2, the installation passes but the editor fails to start.  From versions onwards, such as 1.19 and 1.18, the package dependency is made apparent before installation.

data.title: Find and Replace not working when there's a samba mount
data.body:
If I do a directory search that has samba mount, the search will fail and stop after indexing to the mount folder. The mount folder has large video files. Even if I have added the mount path to the .gitignore file with exclude VCS ignored paths option checked it still produces the same result. If I have unmounted that folder everything will work just fine.
Atom version 1.19.2 on OSX

data.title: Don't select when typing while also holding the left mouse button
data.body:
Fixes https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/15217
Fixes https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/15405

This pull-request addresses a regression that was causing edits performed while users were holding the left mouse button to result in unwanted selections.

| Before                                                                                                        | After                                                                                                        |
|---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| ![before](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/482957/29560759-615f5b22-8733-11e7-98e8-72a79b1e28dc.gif) | ![after](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/482957/29560760-617e3628-8733-11e7-937e-5fe55a16b974.gif) |

Back in Atom 1.18, we used to handle this subtle behavior via an `onWillChange` event subscription on the buffer:

https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/783cda8642e42e842a7aac761f267e151f3db324/src/text-editor-component.coffee#L727

And this pull-request uses the same strategy to work around the problem.

/cc: @nathansobo @Ben3eeE @ungb

data.title: Moving lines by control-command up/down goes wrong
data.body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=âœ“&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

When I select some lines and want to move it, the editor will also move the line what I don't want to move, or missing some selected lines.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Insert some random lines.
2. Select the last 2 lines.
3. Moving up 3 times by `control + command + â†‘`

**Expected behavior:** [What you expect to happen]

![8 -22-2017 13-41-48](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5051791/29550667-7867a320-8741-11e7-9962-da3e4a37e460.gif)


**Actual behavior:** [What actually happens]

![error1](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5051791/29550664-73027b08-8741-11e7-84a4-9e18994e17b8.gif)
![error2](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5051791/29550665-7460ef02-8741-11e7-812c-3ac5e63b8413.gif)

**Reproduces how often:** [What percentage of the time does it reproduce?]

Sometimes.

### Versions

You can get this information from copy and pasting the output of `atom --version` and `apm --version` from the command line. Also, please include the OS and what version of the OS you're running.

OS: macOS Sierra 10.12.6

```bash
atom --version

Atom    : 1.19.2
Electron: 1.6.9
Chrome  : 56.0.2924.87
Node    : 7.4.0
```

```bash
apm --version

apm  1.18.4
npm  3.10.10
node 6.9.5 x64
python 2.7.10
git 2.6.4
```

### Additional Information

I'm using trackpad as mouse and not holding any buttons when moving, but I think it's related to #15217.

data.title: Lint Errors Obscure Autocomplete Suggestions
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [ ] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=âœ“&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

Apologies if this is the wrong repo or this has already been reported (I tried searching a bit before posting). Since updating to 1.19.x I have noticed that linting errors show up more aggressively as I type hiding the autocomplete suggestions (see screenshot).

![atom-screenshot](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1195080/29533988-1cee71c8-8669-11e7-8f9c-574374d85a15.png)

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Start typing (almost anything will trigger lint errors as you type)
2. The lint error shows above any autocomplete suggestions

**Expected behavior:** The autocomplete should be visible

**Actual behavior:** The linter error obscures the autocomplete

**Reproduces how often:** ~90% of the time (not always but almost)

### Versions

I'm on Windows 10 build 1607

Atom    : 1.19.2
Electron: 1.6.9
Chrome  : 56.0.2924.87
Node    : 7.4.0

apm  1.18.4
npm  3.10.10
node 6.9.5 ia32
python
git 2.11.1.windows.1
visual studio

### Additional Information

I'm using linter-eslint v8.2.1. Maybe this is a bug for that repo, but I'm posting it here since it worked perfectly before update to Atom 1.19 and it seems like there have been some changes in core related to linting lately.

data.title: Dark scrollbars over dark syntax themes in macOS (only in editor)
data.body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=âœ“&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

When using a dark syntax theme, the scrollbars in macOS are too dark to be seen correctly. This only happens in the editor (1). For the tree view (2), for example, the color of the scrollbars is as expected (light themed).

![complete](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/9105693/29528771-797e14b4-869d-11e7-9120-54fdc09cebe4.png)

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Select **When scrolling** setting in *macOS Preferences > General > Show scroll bars*.
2. Select a **dark syntax theme** in Atom.

**Expected behavior:** Editor uses light scrollbar on syntax themes with dark backgrounds.

**Actual behavior:** Editor uses dark scrollbar on syntax themes with dark backgrounds, rendering them almost invisible.

**Reproduces how often:** I've test it with all default UI and syntax themes combinations and problem persists.

### Versions

Atom    : 1.19.2
Electron: 1.6.9
Chrome  : 56.0.2924.87
Node    : 7.4.0

apm  1.18.4
npm  3.10.10
node 6.9.5 x64
python 2.7.10
git 2.11.0

OS: macOS Sierra 10.12.6

data.title: Improve handling of "Editor has crashed"
data.body:
### Prerequisites
* NOT able to reproduce in safe mode
* All the diagnosis steps are too complex for a programmer not mentioning a normal user - I have not followed that at all.... you should automate it in some way

### Description

Atom editor is crashing on Windows 10 x64 with windows dialogue "Editor has crashed".
Search your issues - there are many similar.
**Please, improve auto-diagnostic.**
Example similar issue #10717
I'm writing this one just to keep the information somewhere - you can close it immediatelly

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Use atom editor (with plugins)
2. At some point encounter the "editor has crashed" issue with no further details, no windows event log entries, no guidance on how to diagnose the issue
3. Run in safe mode and see that it disables plugins but works.... but still have no idea what might be wrong or what to do next
4. One-by-one move directories from ~/.atom/packages (and then move them back) - at some point it will stop crashing (in my case this was git-gui causing the issue)

**Expected behavior:**
Handle crash scenarios. Provide feedback for the user. Provide instructions for error handling.

**Actual behavior:**
Dummy message saying "report the issue on github" appears.

**Reproduces how often:**
100% reproducibility after atom is started

### Versions
apm  1.18.4
npm  3.10.10
node 6.9.5 x64
python
git 2.13.0.windows.1
visual studio

### Additional Information

data.title: Unable to Check for Updates?
data.body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Description

After downloading the **:atom: atom** [1.19.2](https://github.com/atom/atom/releases/tag/v1.19.2) update and restarting atom I received the following alert:

> __There was an error checking for updates__
> The command is disabled and cannot be executed

Atom seems to be working fine and the update did install, but before that I couldn't even get the update to install. I would keep having to download the update and restart atom, but the update didn't install and I would just get this alert.

data.title: Syntaxhighlighting broken for "Shell Script" highlight mode in HERE documents
data.body:
When using the highlight mode "Shell Script", HERE-documents are not recognized. 

For example, I have in my program code like this:

  cat << EOS
....
EOS

The code between the cat line and the closing EOS is highlighted as if it would be normal program code. This is in particular nasty, if this text contains a single (unpaired) quote, because the highlighter would then search for a matching quote in the code after the closing EOS, and the whole syntax highlightning is garbled.

I can provide a screenshot by email, if needed. I tried to upload a screenshot using this web interface, but it did not work.

I'm using Atom 1.16.0 x64 on Windows 7

You can get this information from copy and pasting the output of `atom --version` and `apm --version` from the command line. Also, please include the OS and what version of the OS you're running.

Node    : 7.4.0

### Additional Info

I didn't change permissions for `/etc/hosts`, all my setup is the same as it was before, except for possibly some language-specific Atom plugins.

data.title: Soft Tabs Malfunction ~ Size is always 1 space, every language
data.body:
### Prerequisites

 * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging
> The nature of this problem does not allow me to do this. ALL other prerequisites are met!

### Description

When tab type is set to soft, size being set to **Anything** and `Soft Tabs` checkbox Editor configuration option being either checked or not checked, the tab size of _every single existing file is automatically auto indented to one space tab size_ and manipulating any other options doesn't effect the problem. 

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Install latest [KDE Neon](https://neon.kde.org/develop) GNU/Linux distribution (Either should be fine)
2. Install atom / atom beta (ditto behavior)
3. Possibly copy my editor setup using [my config](https://pastebin.com/NWN5GAFh), or even [my styles](https://pastebin.com/4b60zAFr)

**Expected behavior:** Tab size isn't autoindented to 1 space and using the autoindent editor command makes an effect after changing the tab size and/or type.

**Actual behavior:** Tab size is stuck at 1 space. Using hard tabs and **only manually indenting** all of every file will yield me the desired tab size at the expense of having to use hard tabs. 

**Reproduces how often:** Indefinitely

### Versions

> ` atom --version && apm --version && atom-beta --version`
Atom    : 1.19.0
Electron: 1.6.9
Chrome  : 56.0.2924.87
Node    : 7.4.0
apm  1.18.2
npm  3.10.10
node 6.9.5 x64
python 2.7.12
git 2.7.4
Atom    : 1.20.0-beta0
Electron: 1.6.9
Chrome  : 56.0.2924.87
Node    : 7.4.0
`uname -romi`
4.10.0-32-generic x86_64 x86_64 GNU/Linux
`lsb_release -a`
No LSB modules are available.
Distributor ID: neon
Description:    KDE neon Developer Edition
Release:        16.04
Codename:       xenial
`kf5-config --version`
Qt: 5.9.1
KDE Frameworks: 5.37.0
kf5-config: 1.0
`plasmashell --version`
plasmashell 5.10.4
`kwin --version`
kwin 5.10.4
`krunner --version`
krunner 5.10.4
`kded5 --version`
kded5 5.37.0

### Additional Information

Please offer me any other workarounds. I bet it'll take a while to propagate a fix to lowly Linux and this issue addles my workflow :(
Note that I launch atom with [this](https://pastebin.com/JMgqGyVH) script called molecule to overcome frustrating issue [#8455](https://github.com/electron/electron/issues/8455)
Feel free to inquire about additional OS or editor information needed. I can offer extensive detail about customizations to the interface as KDE is quite customizable.
Thank you for such a awesome code editor!

data.title: Convert CommandRegistry to JavaScript
data.body:
This was bootstrapped with running `decaffeinate` on both command-registry and its spec, but involved a line-by-line eyeing and updating for idioms, style, and in one case correctness:

For some reason, copying the keys to the new dispatchedEvent in coffeescript (command-registry.coffee:235) currently does not result in a thrown exception, as it should when trying to write over the read-only property `isTrusted`, so I added a check to ensure that the key did not already exist in the new event. Moreover, other definitions of `preventDefault`, `stopPropagation` and friends, which are also enumerable afaict, would also overwrite the ones defined just prior (command-registry.coffee:220 and command-registry.js:325), so that check ensures we don't overwrite those either.

Test plan: `./script/lint && ./script/test`, and a lengthy smoke test of various commands through keybindings, command palette, and package interfaces.

Released under CC0.

data.title: [Atom development] Move linter dependencies to root package.json
data.body:
Atom's linter configurations are stored in the root, but since they were only used in files under `scripts/`, their npm dependencies were stored `scripts/package.json`. This meant that tools like the `coffeelint` and `standard` integrations for Atom couldn't find those binaries from `src/`, `spec/`, etc and either fell back to bundled or global versions (as did Atom's `linter-coffeescript`) which mismatched the lcoal installation, or simply failed silently (as with `linter-js-standard` and `linter-js-standard-engine`).

This change makes the correct versions available to these tools, and they remain accessible from `scripts/` so long as the root as its dependencies installed.

Somewhat unrelated: would you be opposed to me documenting my experience getting Atom dev up and running in a section next to `Building` in the project README? Could also mention these packages and how to build Atom using Atom itself.

Open to alternative suggestions to get these tools to play properly while developing Atom with Atom :)

Released under CC0.

data.title: Use standard (eslint's) 'env' field over globals
data.body:
Test Plan: ensure every removed global is a part of an added `env` from https://github.com/sindresorhus/globals/blob/master/globals.json

run `./script/lint`

Released under CC0

data.title: Uncaught TypeError: Cannot read property 'props' of undefined
data.body:

1. ...
2. ...

data.title: Fix line number position when block decorations are at tile boundaries
data.body:
When there are block decorations, we compute a `marginTop` style for line numbers, so that they can be aligned correctly to the corresponding line nodes.

This pull-request fixes a regression in the logic that calculated the `marginTop` value, which was failing to correctly render line numbers when block decorations were located right before the end of a tile, or exactly at the beginning of it.

| Before | After |
|--------|-------|
| ![screen shot 2017-08-19 at 15 41 35](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/482957/29487170-49e4d642-84f5-11e7-894f-2e8604633f66.png) | ![screen shot 2017-08-19 at 15 43 15](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/482957/29487172-4f5bbe38-84f5-11e7-9eb0-c18acc87a1a9.png) |

@Ben3eeE @50Wliu @ungb: I don't think this regression has been reported yet, but please feel free to test it and close any issue that may be related to this.

/cc: @nathansobo

data.title: [linux] Focus of atom editor over opened apps
data.body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [x ] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=âœ“&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

On linux (Ubuntu 17.04) and atom (1.19.2), atom vampirizes the focus: I cannot cycle through open apps anymore (Alt+Tab), nor gain focus over an open app.

I must minimize atom with a system shortcut (Alt+F9) or right click on the taskbar + minimize, in order to switch applications.
When clicking an open item on my taskbar, atom stays as the active app (foreground).

This issue didn't appear in 1.18.x

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open atom
2. Open a terminal (e.g. Ctrl+Alt+T, system shortcut), or Alt+Tab to select an opened app

**Expected behavior:** Terminal (or whatever app) gains focus (foreground) over atom

**Actual behavior:** Terminal (or whatever app) stays in background, cannot gain focus with the mouse/keyboard

**Reproduces how often:** 100%

### Versions
```bash
$ atom --version
Atom    : 1.19.2
Electron: 1.6.9
Chrome  : 56.0.2924.87
Node    : 7.4.0

$ apm --version
apm  1.18.4
npm  3.10.10
node 6.9.5 x64
python 2.7.13
git 2.11.0

$ lsb_release -a
LSB Version:	core-9.20160110ubuntu5-amd64:core-9.20160110ubuntu5-noarch:security-9.20160110ubuntu5-amd64:security-9.20160110ubuntu5-noarch
Distributor ID:	Ubuntu
Description:	Ubuntu 17.04
Release:	17.04
Codename:	zesty

$ uname -a
Linux m4700 4.10.0-32-generic #36-Ubuntu SMP Tue Aug 8 12:10:06 UTC 2017 x86_64 x86_64 x86_64 GNU/Linux
```

### Additional Information

data.title: Pushing to GitHub extremely slow
data.body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=âœ“&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

Extreme slowness when pushing to github from Atom using the GitHub functionality

### Steps to Reproduce

1. [Open Atom]
2. [Open a git project folder]
3. [Make some changes]
4. [Stage, commit, and try pushing from within Atom]

**Expected behavior:** [Pushing with `git push` from the terminal takes less than 5 seconds]

**Actual behavior:** [Pushing in Atom takes several minutes]

**Reproduces how often:** [100% of the time]

### Versions

$ atom --version
Atom    : 1.19.2
Electron: 1.6.9
Chrome  : 56.0.2924.87
Node    : 7.4.0
$ apm --version
apm  1.18.4
npm  3.10.10
node 6.9.5 x64
python 2.7.12
git 2.7.4
OS Linux Mint 18.2

### Additional Information

It is noted that pushing eventually does occur, however nowhere near as quickly as it does from a terminal.
